text: Elizabeth Warren quickly goes from soft-spoken emotion about her mother taking a minimum wage job at Sears to save the family, to loud-spoken outrage about a system that no longer allows a family to live on a minimum wage salary.

text:
Question: What is your pathway to victory? 

Beto O’Rourke: “Being everywhere.”
author: mviser

text:
Beto O’Rourke on his criticism over comments about Amy raising kids “sometimes with my help.” 

"It’s absolutely valid criticism. It is constructive criticism. Not only will I not say that again but I’ll be much more thoughtful going forward in the way I talk about our marriage."
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke says his attempts at near-complete transparency are a result of his wife: "Amy reminded me, and is really the leader in the family and has the best judgment. She said you’ve got to be this way...I’m doing the best to be as open as I possibly can.”
author: mviser

text: “Life is too short to live in fear,” Beto O’Rourke says. "It doesn’t mean some things don’t scare me. From my second day on the campaign trail running for president, there’s a lot that can be terrifying.”
author: mviser

text: "I have to take ownership of my words,” Beto O’Rourke says. "Whatever my intention was as a teenager, it doesn’t matter. I have to look long and hard at my actions, at the language I have used, and I have to constantly try to do better."
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke on comparisons to President Obama: "He’s an extraordinary human being. The greatest president of my lifetime. I have to be honest, I’m flattered by any comparison. But I know myself well enough to know I don’t come anywhere close."
author: mviser

text: He then gives a shout-out to Sub Arena in Fort Madison. And says he’s heard “mixed reviews” of Taco John’s.

text:
Best thing you’ve eaten since in Iowa? Bonus points if it came with ranch.

Beto O’Rourke: "I’m really embarrassed to tell you my last two dinners have been at Subway."

Question: What is the weirdest thing that happened to you since becoming a national figure?

Beto O’Rourke: "People wearing t-shirts with your name on them is amazing."

text: “I hope as much as we can we can focus on the big issues,” he adds. “All I can do is my best...I can’t control anything that I’ve done in the past I can just control what I do in the future.”

text:
Older man walks into an Iowa coffee shop, looking around.

“You looking for something?” an employee asks.

“Presidential candidate.”

“Next door.”

text: Beto O’Rourke is back at an Iowa coffee shop, and back standing on a countertop.
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke is asked if he supports reparations. He launches into an impassioned answer, saying “we have systemic racism in this country,” “it’s important to have this conversation,” and it’s time for “a reckoning.” But doesn’t provide a yes or no on if he supports reparations.
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke, asked about the two-minute Club for Growth ad: “This is the sincerest form of flattery.”

text: Before he became the darling of liberal online donors, Beto O'Rourke benefited from the donations of businessmen who favored Republicans. Via @michaelscherer
author: mviser

text:
Beto is asked about adding more Supreme Court justices.

“Given the fact we are at the most dysfunctional points...it calls for creative solutions.” He says it’s “an idea we should explore.” Also mentions having terms for justices. But doesn’t commit to any plan.
author: mviser

text: Beto from the countertop at the Beancounter in Burlington, Iowa.
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke concludes his talk in Fort Mitchell, Iowa, by thanking them for the hospitality — and offering to return the favor. “If you ever need a place in El Paso, look me up,” he says.
author: mviser

text:
Voter in Fort Madison, Iowa: “You’ve been the hottest ticket for months now...why pick us? Why did you come here?”

Beto O’Rourke: “Everyone is important to me. No one can be written off...I want to show up everywhere for everyone.”
author: mviser

text:
Beto O’Rourke asked about his short resume, and possible criticism of it. “I may not have served forever...but I have served in different ways.” Recounts time in El Paso on the city council.

“We need to come together, damn the differences,” he continues, “and get it done.”
author: mviser

text:
A voter in Iowa earnestly asks Beto O’Rourke: “Now that you’re running, have you considered going on the show @TheView?”

“I don’t know that I’m in the business of turning anyone away,” he says. “If they’ll have me, sure.”
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke enters a sub shop in southeastern Iowa and shouts “Hola!” Then launches into a no-notes pitch he’s continuing to develop.

text: Perhaps it’s true that few may rival Beto’s hand movement. But Trump is certainly one who would.

text: Beto O’Rourke is youthful, goes viral and has a thin political record. Joe Biden is older, still exploring social media and has a decades-long resume that could both help and haunt. My look at the two missing pieces in the 2020 puzzle:
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden, 76, and Beto O’Rourke, 46, are Irish American white males who would be entering a field that is the most diverse in history in a party now energized by minorities and women. My look at two big missing pieces in the 2020 puzzle: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/orourke-and-biden-nearing-a-potential-collision-course/2019/03/12/299d1288-44c4-11e9-90f0-0ccfeec87a61_story.html?utm_term=.3983f3cd818c …
author: mviser

text: O’Rourke and Biden would be trying to lay claim to the Obama legacy, with Biden touting his eight-year partnership in the White House and O’Rourke attempting to tap into the cultural and generational zeitgeist as Obama did more than a decade ago. https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/orourke-and-biden-nearing-a-potential-collision-course/2019/03/12/299d1288-44c4-11e9-90f0-0ccfeec87a61_story.html?utm_term=.3983f3cd818c …
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke is youthful, goes viral and has a short political record. Joe Biden is older, still exploring social media and has a decades-long resume of successes and mistakes. My look at how O’Rourke and Biden could be on something of a collision course:

text: "Not hyperbole. Living by the motto. Duty. Integrity. Respect. You guys live by that motto but I’m not sure you know how much you embody it,” Joe Biden says. "Not a joke. Not a joke."

text: "Did you see the budget just introduced? It cuts — it cuts — $845 billion. Almost a trillion dollar cut in Medicare. Almost quarter trillion cut in Medicaid,” Joe Biden says. "Why? Because of a tax cut for the superwealthy."

text: Joe Biden, working up the room over collective bargaining. “Reminds me of the fight we had in ’86 over overtime for firefighters,” he says.

text: “I appreciate the energy you showed when I got up here,” Joe Biden says, referring to the “Run Joe Run” chants. "Save it a little longer. I may need it in a few weeks.” Then, he adds, “Be careful what you wish for. Be careful what you wish for."

text: Joe Biden says his wife Jill puts up messages on the mirror, where he shaves. One of them was: "Stop trying to make me love you.” Then, he quips, "She put it up two weeks ago."

text:
Joe Biden takes the stage to chants “Run! Joe! Run!” “Run! Joe! Run!”

"I promise you I didn’t know Adlai Stevenson,” he says to start. “But he said flattery is fine as long as you don’t inhale.””

text: Pete Buttigieg on Mike Pence: “How can he allow himself to be the cheerleader for the porn star presidency? Is it that he stopped believing in scripture when he started believing in Donald Trump? I don’t know. I don’t know.”
author: mviser

text: Pete Buttigieg, I learned yesterday from @anamariecox’s questioning, would be the first president who was an only child.
author: mviser

text: Tulsi Gabbard is asked what being the first female president would mean to her. The answer is fairly robotic: “The more important question is what would it mean to the country?”
author: mviser

text: Tulsi Gabbard complains about using labels to define one’s ideology, saying doing so is often done to pit people against each another. “I’m a Democrat,” she proclaims. Which is a label, meant to define one’s ideology.
author: mviser

text: Trump’s massive reelection campaign has 2016 themes — and a 2020 infrastructure, by @ToluseO @jdawsey1
author: mviser

text: Bernie Sanders has been an anomaly among the Democrats vying for the White House, as he routinely utters two words that other candidates have often avoided: “Donald Trump.”  via @CleveWootson
author: mviser

text: 2020 candidates tee off on big tech at the big tech festival #SXSW, via @daveweigel in the new Trailer:
author: mviser

text: Spotted in Austin, getting ready to head back to El Paso with family in tow (after a line of surprised onlookers forms for photos)
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke won the adulation of a SXSW crowd anticipating a presidential run, even as a new documentary showed how his 2018 Senate campaign pained his children. @WPJenna on the privilege and price of celebrity
author: mviser

text: The 2020 circus merges with the SXSW circus. My look at how the left-leaning millennial crowd here — riding in on a fleet of electric scooters — is highly sought by primary candidates trying to create viral moments and seeking the sheen of authenticity.
author: mviser

text: Bill Weld, asked whether he would pardon President Trump the way that Gerald Ford pardoned Richard Nixon: “I assume you’re joking. No! I would not consider it."
author: mviser

text: "My wife and I wouldn’t allow our kids to have gameboys,” Bill Weld says. "I yearn for the good old days of mimeograph machines."
author: mviser

text: “It’s a death spiral embrace,” Bill Weld says of the two parties both being to blame for the current state of politics. “It takes two for a death spiral embrace."
author: mviser

text: “I’m not rejoining the party I left. I am rejoining the party, I hope, of Lincoln,” says Bill Weld, the former GOP governor of Massachusetts. Then goes into a history of the Know-Nothing Party.
author: mviser

text: Elizabeth Warren brings her message of breaking up the country’s biggest tech companies to one of the county’s biggest tech conferences.
author: mviser

text: Pete Buttigieg on the reparations debate: "It’s being used as a cudgel because nobody can explain what it actually means."
author: mviser

text: Pete Buttigieg, asked about learning about privilege, tells a story of getting caught by a cop smoking marijuana while at Harvard. He was let go. "If I were not white the odds of that being something that could have derailed my life are exponentially greater."
author: mviser

text:
How many books do you read a year? 

Elizabeth Warren: “Probably two a week"

Seriously?

Warren: "I do a lot of books on tape.” Also, she adds, “I read a lot of trash.” (She’s currently on fifth book in the series of Victor the Assassin)
author: mviser

text:
Q: Is AOC under-hyped or overhyped?

Elizabeth Warren: Right hyped
author: mviser

text:
Reparations, yes or no?

Elizabeth Warren: “It’s time to start the conversation."
author: mviser

text:
Q: Is Donald Trump a racist?

Elizabeth Warren: “Yes"
author: mviser

text: Elizabeth Warren: “The relationship between the United States government and the tribal nations has been one in which our own federal government has failed repeatedly. We have obligations that we have failed to live up to."
author: mviser

text: Asked what doubt she has about whether she may be wrong on some aspect of her philosophy, Elizabeth Warren says, "I always wonder about...additional data I don’t have yet, that I haven’t seen."
author: mviser

text:
Q: Before getting into the race, did Bernie Sanders discourage you from running. And if so what grounds?

Elizabeth Warren pauses for a few seconds before saying, "Bernie and I had a private dinner. My view is that dinner stays private."
author: mviser

text: Elizabeth Warren on the impact of her proposal to break up large tech companies: "The monopolists will make fewer monopoly profits. Boo-who."
author: mviser

text: "I am a bozo and a hypocrite and a failure, and I know that,” John Kasich says. "But tomorrow is going to be a better day. For whatever."
author: mviser

text: John Kasich: “Women -- thank God they’re gaining more power, thank God they’re gaining more influence.”
author: mviser

text: John Kasich on if he'll challenge President Trump and run in 2020: "I’m not into Hail Mary. I run when I think I can win. We assess things. About every week or every day. I’m not closing anything down. I just don’t know yet."
author: mviser

text: “I think we’re going to look back on this period and say, ‘That was just crazy. It was nuts.’” — John Kasich
author: mviser

text: “Just pass comprehensive immigration reform,” John Kasich says. “What are we waiting for?"
author: mviser

text: John Kasich on his position during the 2016 Republican primary debates: "I was so far off in the wings that I felt like a Ugandan swimmer at the Olympics."
author: mviser

text: "I’m just trying to tell you I’m a slob trying to make it through.” — John Kasich
author: mviser

text: "None of us are pure, we’re all hypocrites,” John Kasich says. "I’ll be the number one hypocrite in the room.”
author: mviser

text: “I’m driving a Tesla,” John Kasich says to the #SXSW crowd. “How about a round of applause for that?” Applause ensues.
author: mviser

text: John Kasich, at #SXSW, speaking about Republicans: “My party has devolved.”
author: mviser

text: Amy Klobuchar says she recently sat down with Jimmy Carter and, over pimento cheese sandwiches, he gave her advice on running a presidential campaign.
author: mviser

text: Asked about impeaching President Trump, Amy Klobuchar says that as a senator, "we are in a different position we are the jury.” "I never comment on evidence,” she adds.
author: mviser

text: Amy Klobuchar on the 47 month sentence for Paul Manafort: "That was appalling to me."
author: mviser

text:
A variety of presidential candidates are here at #SXSW earnestly pitching themselves and their ideas.

In several conversations, attendees seem more concerned with Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, and where she is going to eat her tacos.
author: mviser

text:
Should Facebook or Google be broken up?

Amy Klobuchar: "I would want to have it investigated. That is how I do things."
author: mviser

text: "There are a number of great candidates,” Amy Klobuchar says. "There really are. I like to jokingly say: May be best woman win."
author: mviser

text: Amy Klobuchar on how to deal with Trump: "I will use humor.” Notes that after he made fun of her in the blizzard, she said: "You know what I’d like to see how your hair will work in a blizzard, Mr. Umbrella Man."
author: mviser

text: Less than 10 minutes into her forum here at #SXSW, Amy Klobuchar has twice mentioned John McCain.
author: mviser

text: "Yes we can be as good as Iceland,” Amy Klobuchar says, clarifying that is not her campaign slogan. She’s referring to rural broadband.
author: mviser

text: Asked if coverage of her and the complaints that she is a bad boss are sexist, Amy Klobuchar says: “I’m not going to go there…I just can’t waste my time analyzing it."
author: mviser

text: Amy Klobuchar at #SXSW: “The comb story was about me doing a mom thing. I didn’t have a fork. I used a comb, very briefly, on a plane."
author: mviser

text: “I am pleased to be the PT Barnum of this weekend’s circus,” @evanasmith says ahead of a series of discussions with presidential candidates.
author: mviser

text: “I believe there will be an NBA team coming back to Seattle,” Howard Schultz says to conclude his talk at #SXSW
author: mviser

text: Democrats have donkey, Republicans have elephant. Howard Schultz is asked what his "spirit animal" will be. He says he’ll take suggestions, and someone in the crowd shouts: Unicorn.
author: mviser

text:
"If you want a good description of socialism just look at Venezuela,” Howard Schultz says as some in the #SXSW crowd jeer.

"You don’t like that?” he asks. "We don’t want a government takeover of our lives. We want the freedom of being able to pursue happiness in America."
author: mviser

text: "The country is ready for a Jewish president,” Howard Schultz says. "I’m not running as someone who is Jewish, I’m running as an American who happens to be Jewish.”
author: mviser

text:
Howard Schultz: "We need to raise taxes on wealthy and on corproate America.”

How much? 

"I don’t know what the number is. People a lot smarter than me — but clearly our tax system is out of whack…We need sensible solutions."
author: mviser

text: "The American people agree with me,” Howard Schultz says. "They want to see another choice. I want to play this out and I want to travel the country and see if there’s a national agreement."
author: mviser

text: "We live in America, where anything is possible. We live in American where your dreams can come true,” Howard Schultz says when asked about his viability. "I’m not going to allow the pundits, the cynics, to tell me that what I believe needs to happen in America is not possible."
author: mviser

text: "For Mayor Bloomberg…to realize there was no place for him in the Democratic Party is a litmus test that the party has gone too far to the left,” Howard Schultz says at #SXSW
author: mviser

text: Howard Schultz: "For us to start moving toward a level of socialism is such an extreme position and so inconsistent with the values and heritage of this country. And that is what Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders are proposing.” If they are the nominee, he says, Trump will win.
author: mviser

text: "We’re living in a society right now where you can send a tweet about anything and get 10-15 million followers and you’re an iconic celebrity,” Howard Schultz says.
author: mviser

text: "The two party system is broken, dysfunctional and in need of great repair,” Howard Schultz says to applause at #SXSW
author: mviser

text: The morning scene at #SXSW, as told through a single intersection
author: mviser

text: Helen Thomas looks skeptical...

text:
Jan 20: Bob Kraft visits a spa and allegedly pays for sexual services, before watching Patriots win AFC championship

Feb 3: Founder of the spa watches Patriots win Super Bowl with President Trump at Mar-a-Lago

Feb 22: Kraft charged for soliciting sex

text: Imagine if the whales came ashore and blasted us all with noise – every 10 seconds, for days. Via @bydarrylfears
author: mviser

text: The @washingtonpost podcast #PostReports is worth a listen every single day. Today, we discuss my story about Joe Biden's rhetoric on segregation, busing, and racism -- and how his 1975 views could impact his 2020 political fortunes.
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden spoke out repeatedly and forcefully against diversifying schools through busing. He played down the persistence of overt racism and suggested government should have a limited role in integration. My dive into his potentially problematic past:
author: mviser

text: Biden: “The real problem with busing -- you take people who aren’t racist, people who are good citizens, who believe in equal education & opportunity, and you stunt their children’s intellectual growth by busing them to an inferior school...you’re going to fill them with hatred."
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden, arguing against busing in 1975: “What it says is, ‘In order for your child with curly black hair, brown eyes, and dark skin to be able to learn anything, he needs to sit next to my blond-haired, blue-eyed son.’ That’s racist!" https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/bidens-tough-talk-on-1970s-school-desegregation-plan-could-get-new-scrutiny-in-todays-democratic-party/2019/03/07/9115583e-3eb2-11e9-a0d3-1210e58a94cf_story.html?utm_term=.c52351cd6209 …
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden, deeply opposed to busing, in 1975 argued "We’ve lost our bearings since the 1954 Brown vs. School Board desegregation case. To ‘desegregate’ is different than to ‘integrate.’ I am philosophically opposed to quota systems. They insure mediocrity” https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/bidens-tough-talk-on-1970s-school-desegregation-plan-could-get-new-scrutiny-in-todays-democratic-party/2019/03/07/9115583e-3eb2-11e9-a0d3-1210e58a94cf_story.html?utm_term=.c52351cd6209 …
author: mviser

text: “I do not buy the concept, popular in the ’60s, which said, ‘We have suppressed the black man for 300 years'" Joe Biden said in 1975. "I feel responsible...for the sins of my own generation. And I’ll be damned if I feel responsible to pay for what happened 300 years ago.”
author: mviser

text:
NEW: A dive into Joe Biden’s tough talk on 1970s school desegregation plans -- and how it could get new scrutiny in today’s Democratic Party. My latest:  
https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/bidens-tough-talk-on-1970s-school-desegregation-plan-could-get-new-scrutiny-in-todays-democratic-party/2019/03/07/9115583e-3eb2-11e9-a0d3-1210e58a94cf_story.html?utm_term=.c52351cd6209 …
author: mviser

text: The potential Democratic field shrinks more: Sen. Sherrod Brown, Democrat from Ohio, won’t run for president per @daveweigel and @chelsea_janes
author: mviser

text: NEW: Sherrod Brown won’t run for president. “The best place for me to make that fight is in the United States Senate.”

text: NEW: Former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg bows out of 2020 Democratic presidential contest via @michaelscherer

text: No one plays D quite like Duke.

text: I can truthfully say I don’t know, nor have I threatened, Stormy Daniels! (and always thought the sketch looked more like Tom Brady)

text: Quite a scene in Selma today on the 54th anniversary of Bloody Sunday.
author: mviser

text: Selma.
author: mviser

text: "The dream is under attack. The dreamers are in danger. And we need each other more that we realize in this country,” Cory Booker says from the pulpit in historic Brown’s Chapel in Selma, Ala.
author: mviser

text: "My roots go back to slavery,” Cory Booker says in Selma. "Rose up from poverty and segregation. Rose up from black churches, through civil rights organizations"
author: mviser

text: Cory Booker pays tribute from the pulpit to Hillary Clinton. "She won the election,” someone in the congregation says. "She got more votes,” Booker responds. “She got more votes."
author: mviser

text: During a break in the service here at historic Brown’s Chapel in Selma, Hillary Clinton takes out her phone and begins scrolling. Cory Booker fetches a small bottled water for Jesse Jackson.
author: mviser

text: “We can take back this country,” Hillary Clinton says to conclude remarks in Selma, as the congregation in Brown’s Chapel rises to its feet.
author: mviser

text: "Between 2012, the prior presidential election where we still had the Voting Rights Act, and 2016, when I was on the ballot, there were fewer voters in Georgia than there were in the prior election,” Clinton adds. “Think about it"
author: mviser

text: “I was the first to run without the Voting Rights Act,” Hillary Clinton says. "And I can tell you, it does make a difference."
author: mviser

text: "Never forget,” Hillary Clinton tells a congregation in Selma. "There is another side in America. And they never give up…they are motivated every single day to try to suppress rights.”
author: mviser

text: Hillary Clinton and Cory Booker, arriving to a service filled with clapping, praying, and shouts of “hallelujah,” inside Brown’s Chapel in Selma, Alabama.
author: mviser

text: It is! And wish I had a link at this moment to pass along. There are cameras here so footage should emerge!
author: mviser

text: I’m in the room. And not sure if there’s a livestream
author: mviser

text: “Stacey Abrams should be governor,” Hillary Clinton says, making the case of voter suppression in Georgia and elsewhere.
author: mviser

text: “Make no mistake,” Hillary Clinton says in Selma. “We are living through a full-fledged crisis of our democracy.”
author: mviser

text: Man presenting Hillary Clinton with “international unity award” outlines why: “She was elected president of the United States, and it was stolen from her,” he says, as crowd stands for ovation. “It was stolen from her by the FBI...it was stolen from her by the Russians.”
author: mviser

text: When Cory Booker left the stage here in Selma, Hillary Clinton stood and gave a big hug. The warmth was palpable. When Bernie Sanders left the stage, she stood and, as he was briskly walking past, it appeared they briefly shook hands. The chilliness was palpable.
author: mviser

text: The George Wallace Community College logo is basically identical to the New England Patriots logo
author: mviser

text: Here in Selma for the Martin and Coretta King Unity Breakfast, where Bernie Sanders (as well as Cory Booker and Sherrod Brown) will speak and Hillary Clinton will be honored...at a community college named after George Wallace.
author: mviser

text: In the 2020 primary, with a historically diverse field, black voters have quickly become a highly-sought-after electoral prize. The early courtship’s playing out in complex ways, a dynamic that becomes more visible Sunday in Selma. From me & @CleveWootson:
author: mviser

text: From cursing about Trump to calling out a "racist act," Rep. Rashida Tlaib has leaned into her reputation as provocative congresswoman. Back home, residents only hope it will help, via @newsbysamuels :
author: mviser

text: In a divided America, and a moment when the country has never seemed angrier, talk has turned to something unspoken for 150 years: civil war. Insightful read from @gregjaffe and @WPJenna
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke and his advisers are sending strong signals that he’s on the brink of announcing a run for president, a move that would conclude a period of public and private introspection and alter the complexion of the crowded 2020 field. My latest:
author: mviser

text: I don’t know that this is a hill I’m willing to die on, but...
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden, after calling Mike Pence "a decent guy," is now making a point to say that his views are not "decent."
author: mviser

text: Beto is a biker. And gets the full @BicyclingMag treatment:
author: mviser

text: "I don't know how he wrote 'Art of the Deal,'" Joe Biden says. "I don't know how the hell that sold."
author: mviser

text: "I have traveled almost every inch of Afghanistan in a helicopter" -- Joe Biden
author: mviser

text: Former Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel on President Trump's meeting with Kim Jong-un: "It was interesting. Good entertainment on television for 24 hours. But it was embarrassing. It was embarrassing.”
author: mviser

text: "The president treats everything like it’s a real estate deal -- I'm not being a wise guy," Joe Biden says of Trump and North Korea talks. "'Just let me in the room and I can get the other people to make a deal.' Well it requires, hard, hard, hard, consistent diplomacy."
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden, being Joe Biden: "Folks, there's nothing we can't do. I really mean it. Not a joke."
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden knocking Trump: "The love affair, love letters, with Kim Jong-un. Standing before the world and taking the word of Vladimir Putin over the entire intelligence community. Dealing with a thug in the Philippines. I could go on. Our national reputation’s being tarnished."
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden recounts how, while he was in Munich, his successor Mike Pence (“a guy who’s a decent guy”) said he was there on behalf of President Trump. “It was dead silence,” Biden says. “Dead silence. The fact of the matter is, they in fact no longer trust our commitment.”
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden, speaking in Omaha, notes at the outset, "My buddy Bill Nelson is here." (The former senator from Florida was also with Biden on Tuesday in Delaware, and got a similar shout-out)
author: mviser

text: Beto on a single speed bike (and no helmet)
author: mviser

text: Beto O'Rourke, amid speculation he'll run for president, is not running for Senate in 2020, reports Dallas Morning News' @gromerjeffers. "Amy and I have made a decision about how we can best serve our country. We are excited to share it with everyone soon"
author: mviser

text: "WE HAVE GOT TO GET BACK TO NORMAL!" Rep. Elijah Cummings says, concluding a very abnormal congressional hearing.
author: mviser

text:
"I am not calling the gentlemen, Mr. Meadows, a racist," Rep Rashida Tlaib says. 

"I'm just saying it is a racist act," she says of him using a black woman as "a prop" to suggest that President Trump is not racist.
author: mviser

text: Just before testifying before Congress in 2017, Michael Cohen says that he went to the White House and spoke with President Trump about his impending testimony. Trump attorney Jay Sekulow was also there.
author: mviser

text:
"I am a nice guy," Michael Cohen claims 

"The record reflects you are not a nice guy!" Rep. Mark Meadows (R-NC) responds
author: mviser

text: Michael Cohen is unable to say how many women he paid off on behalf of President Trump. "It's certainly the two that we know about," he says, referring to Stormy Daniels and Karen McDougal. Seems there might need to be a follow-up question on this.
author: mviser

text: "...But there’s still a couple hurdles to make sure this is all in place," Joe Biden continues. "But I’m not there yet. I don’t want to mislead you." He reiterates: "I have not made the final decision."
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden: "I can die a happy man never having lived in the White House. But what I don’t want to do Is take people’s time, effort and commitment without there being a clear shot I could be the nominee. I think I can. I think that’s where we are...."
author: mviser

text: "We’re also taking a hard look at whether or not this alleged appeal I have -- how deep does it run? Is it real?" Joe Biden says of whether he'll run for president.
author: mviser

text: "I will not be part of a Super PAC," Joe Biden says, while expanding upon his decision-making process for a presidential bid.
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden says that a lot has changed since the last time he was on a ballot. "Between then and now, the whole issue of social media and the use of social media has fundamentally changed," he says.
author: mviser

text: "I don’t want to his to be a fool’s errand," Joe Biden says of a presidential campaign. "I want to make sure if we do this -- and I’m very close to making a decision -- that I am fully prepared to do it."
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden says after several family meetings, "there’s a consensus I should – they…want me to run." He adds: "The first hurdle for me was deciding whether or not I am comfortable taking the family through what would be a very very, very difficult campaign."
author: mviser

text:
Joe Biden says when he first arrived in Senate he didn't know many people. Met them in the gym where, he says, "everybody walks around in their birthday suit." With Ted Kennedy, he met William Fulbright and Jennings Randolph. 
"The first time I met these guys, I saw all of them.”
author: mviser

text: “I have a series of nudity stories about world leaders," Jon Meacham says, attempting to take the discussion with Joe Biden in a different direction...
author: mviser

text:
Jon Meacham says politicians often respond when told to consider what they want people to think about when looking at an oil portrait of them.

Joe Biden: "I don’t have an oil portrait anywhere, I want you to know that."

Meacham: "It’s early yet sir."
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden says he was once asked by Chinese President Xi Jinping if he could define America. He could, he said, in one word: "Possibilities."
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden briefly mentions being the only white lifeguard at a public swimming pool in an African American neighborhood. More on that here:
author: mviser

text: "Barack and I agreed we were not going to comment on President Trump’s administration for a year to give him a chance to get set up…we thought we’d do what W did with us," Joe Biden says. "But when Charlottesville happened, I couldn’t remain silent any longer.”
author: mviser

text:
Jon Meacham: “I’m not a Democrat, I’m not a Republican; I’ve voted for both and plan to continue to.” Looks over at Joe Biden. "That was your cue."

Joe Biden: "I'm treading very carefully here."
author: mviser

text: "We know America stands at a crossroads regardless of what your politics is," Joe Biden says. "We know we’re at a crossroads.”
author: mviser

text: Joe Biden starts event at the University of Delaware by looking out to the crowd and thanking former Sen. Bill Nelson, the Democrat who lost his 2018 reelection bid in Florida, for coming to the event.
author: mviser

text: As we reported two weeks ago, Biden's team has been conducting interviews with potential staff members (and have repeatedly had to add names to their internal hiring lists, as their candidates have signed on to other campaigns)
author: mviser

text: It's unclear if Biden's ready to run, but he's definitely ready to read.

text: Well, this is deflating.

text:
Beto reiterates previous timeline: "I really hope to be able to make a decision by the end of this month.” Adds: "I won't be limited by, you know, the end of this month. But I expect to be able to get to a decision by the end of this month”

(There are 9 days left in this month)
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke to reporters in El Paso: "I'm trying to figure out how I can best serve this country, where I can do the greatest good for the United States of America…It may involve running for the presidency it may involve something else."
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke, continuing to argue against a wall and for limited physical barriers: "I'm just as concerned about border security & safety as anyone. I live here. I'm raising my kids a short walk from the US Mexico border but we won't achieve that safety & security through walls"

text: In thanking family: "Not only believes in me and the person I am, gives me confidence and courage which I so badly need and want and try to use in pursuit of bigger things for all of us. But you also believe in what I can become, not a position or a title…but a better person."

text:
Liberal energy among Democrats is real. But two things to keep in mind:

2) No major GOP contest means unenrolled NH voters may choose to vote in Dem primary.

text: President Trump has installed a room-sized “golf simulator” game at the White House, which allows him to play virtual rounds at courses all over the world by hitting a ball into a large video screen, @jdawsey1 and @Fahrenthold scoop:

text:
“I will fix the VA,” Howard Schultz says.

Ok. How?

“First off, diagnose the problem. We have layers and layers of government bureaucracy…I will fix the VA. It’s about leadership and temperament…I promise you. I will fix the VA.”

text:
Will you sell your shares in Starbucks if you become president?

Howard Schultz: “We’re getting way premature.”

He repeatedly says there would be no conflict of interest if he’s president, without offering any specifics.

text: “I’m running not as an independent, I’m running as an American, wrapping myself in an American flag.” — Howard Schultz on CNN

text: “It’s a lot less about me than it is giving the American people a voice they don’t have.” — Howard Schultz
author: mviser

text: Is there any world in which you would run as a Democrat. “No,” Howard Schultz says matter-of-factly during CNN’s Town Hall.
author: mviser

text:
Howard Schultz: “I should pay more taxes.”

Ok. How much more?

“I don’t know what the number is. What I’m saying is we need comprehensive tax reform.”

How about a ballpark figure?

“Seventy percent is a punitive number.”

What’s not punitive?

“I don’t know what the number is."

text: Howard Schultz: “When I read the Green New Deal and read that by 2030 they’re suggesting every building in America conforms to clean energy? It’s not realistic…Let’s be sensible. Let’s not just throw things against the wall."

text: Trump once lived with a poodle, Chappy, with his first wife, Ivana. "Donald was not a dog fan,” she wrote in her memoir. He said he didn’t want the dog. "'It's me and Chappy or no one!' I insisted, and that was that.” Chappy, she later said, "had an equal dislike of Donald."

text:
“Build that wall!” the crowd chants. Trump corrects them. “Finish that wall.” He claims much of it has already been built.  

The US-Mexico border is 1,954 miles. There’s 654 miles in existing barrier. And as of January, 0 miles of barriers had been added since he took office.

text: Tired of caucusing on a cold winter night? Iowa Democrats move closer to an optional tele-caucus format. My look at what would be the most sweeping changes to the quirky caucus format since its inception in 1972:
author: mviser

text: NH Secretary of State Bill Gardner tells me “so far it doesn’t appear that they’re changing it from a caucus,” but he reserved judgment until the Iowa plan is final. “It’s not all together yet. It’s just mostly an idea or theoretical...but ideas sometimes can morph.”
author: mviser

text: To make it like the in-person caucus, perhaps those participating virtually will be told to stand in a corner somewhere, anywhere. Then they will be placed on hold, and told to wait around while someone tabulates the results.
author: mviser

text: Iowa party officials flew out to NH last year to ensure that whatever changes they made would not trigger NH to move up their primary date. They think the changes they are making will be ok with NH Secretary of State Bill Gardner.
author: mviser

text: Iowa Democrats will also release raw vote totals from the first votes, which will show what share candidates received before taking into account the 15 percent viability threshold needed to advance.
author: mviser

text: These are the most significant changes to the Iowa caucuses since their inception in 1972. They are meant to allow for absentee voting. They also make an already complicated voting system a bit more so.
author: mviser

text: JUST IN: Iowa Democrats are expanding the caucus system for 2020, allowing for six "virtual caucuses" for those who can't make it in-person. They'll take place over the phone, with participants ranking top five choices. 10% of Iowa's delegates will be awarded this way.
author: mviser

text: Amid debates over politics focused on racial and ethnic identity, Democrats are taking pride in a simple fact: the current field of nearly a dozen presidential candidates includes only one heterosexual white male.
author: mviser

text: The past week has seen a combustible collision of politics focused on racial and ethnic identity, highlighting how much the national discourse is being fragmented not only by partisan loyalties, but also by factors innately personal. From me and @WaPoSean: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/different-democratic-controversies-same-influence-identity-politics/2019/02/10/e0c20ef0-2bfb-11e9-b2fc-721718903bfc_story.html?utm_term=.779001383f6e …

text: Beto O’Rourke meets Oprah Winfrey, talks about his time with Obama, gets encouragement from Bradley Cooper — and teases a presidential campaign. My latest from Times Square:
author: mviser

text:
Warren offered fuller apology to tribes: “I can’t go back. But I'm sorry for furthering confusion on tribal sovereignty & tribal citizenship & harm that resulted”

New docs also show she ID'd herself as “American Indian” in 1986 @AnnieLinskey @AmyEGardner:
author: mviser

text: “I hope he runs,” Bradley Cooper says of Beto O’Rourke. “We need inspiration.”
author: mviser

text: "Ok end of the month. What’s today? Couldn’t he say Valentines Day?” Oprah says after Beto leaves. "We should have started with tequila shots. That would have got it out of him."
author: mviser

text: Oprah to Beto: "You seem like you’re getting ready to run.” Beto leans back and smiles. And the interview concludes.
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke pauses for a beat. "Even saying these words, it’s hard to believe that I’m saying I met with Barack Obama. And I’m saying it to Oprah Winfrey.”
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke on if President Obama asked him to run for president: “No he didn’t. He didn’t.” Adds that they did talk about him possibly running, just that Obama wasn’t explicitly encouraging him.
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke on his meeting with President Obama: "I am so tense and tight,” he recalls. He says he “mind controlled my body and expressions and tried to look relaxed"
author: mviser

text: “Someone who works for him served me a cup of coffee in a porcelain cup,” Beto O’Rourke says of meeting with Obama after Oprah asks if refreshments were served.
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke on his decision process about running for president: “I’m increasingly excited about doing something."
author: mviser

text: "The reason I respect your process is I firmly believe you have to feel it within yourself,” Oprah says. "Not what everybody else says, that I believe I can answer this call for this particular moment in our time."
author: mviser

text: Beto turns the tables on Oprah: "Many of the questions you have been asking me, people would like to know the answer form you.” Will she run for president?
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke says of when he’ll decide on running for president: "The serious answer is really soon. Before the end of this month.”
author: mviser

text: It was unclear beforehand what Beto O’Rourke would say to Oprah. Oprah is almost begging him to get in the race. And he is all-but-announcing that he plans to run.
author: mviser

text: Oprah is now trying to talk Beto into giving a definitive yes on running for president, pointing out Obama’s kids got to spend more time with him when he was in the White House.
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke says that the campaign was hardest on his oldest son, because he was away so much. After a few months at home, he says: "Our oldest, Ulysses…is about ready for me to leave the house."
author: mviser

text: Oprah recasts Beto O'Rourke’s explanation, saying that he is leaning toward running for president. He does not correct her.
author: mviser

text:
Oprah: "Will you be running?”

Beto: "That’s a big question for us to think through...You can tell. I’m so excited at the prospect of being able to play that role"

Oprah: "What’s it gonna take!?! What’s it gonna take for you to say yes, I’m doing it?"
author: mviser

text: Beto to Oprah: “I have been thinking about running for president.” Huge cheers
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke on him going on his road trip to get out of his “funk”: “I had to be moving, I had to be meeting people. It’s just how I think, how I find the next step. I just truly emerged out of this by being with people.”
author: mviser

text: "How you come out of your funk at least in my case, you stop looking at yourself. You look at others,” Beto O’Rourke says.
author: mviser

text:
Oprah: When you go home and wake up and it’s done and you didn’t win, is there a sunken place?

Beto: "Yes. Felt a profound disappointment in myself that I had let so many people down."
author: mviser

text: Beto O’Rourke to Oprah: "We’re up to all these challenges. We just need a politics, a representation that reflects our values, our goodness, our kindness."
author: mviser

text:
Oprah: What did the US Senate race teach you?

Beto O’Rourke: "People are so good. The division that we see in our country, the animosity, the conflict, the vilification almost dehumanization for the views that they hold…I didn’t find that when I met people across Texas.”
author: mviser

text: "At a time when so much of our politics is tested and scripted,” Beto O’Rourke says of his US Senate race, he tried to offer “something new and maybe even dangerous.” No speechwriter, no pollster.
author: mviser

text:
Oprah on loss to Ted Cruz: Why do you think you lost?

"I don’t all the way know,” Beto O’Rourke says. "I know we could have won that race."
author: mviser

text: Oprah says she first noticed Beto O’Rourke during the border separations. Told her friend Gayle King to go find him: “He’s a tall guy. He looks sorta like Robert Kennedy or one of those Kennedy guys."
author: mviser

text: “I wanted to know what all the fuss was about,” Oprah says if Beto O’Rourke. “Are you the real deal?”

text: I did not steal my neighbor’s car. I stole his neighbor’s car. And I’m ready to be forgiven.

text: After last night, there is only one legislature in the nation that is divided: Minnesota, where the House is Democratic and the Senate is Republican. text: The Elizabeth Warren midterm effort is also a window into how decentralized the national Democratic Party has become. The energy is being generated not by slogans like "A Better Deal" or "For the People" but by individuals building their own operations. https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/elizabeth-warren-builds-expansive-democratic-campaign-effort-ahead-of-likely-2020-bid/2018/10/14/45f3a0ae-ce5f-11e8-a360-85875bac0b1f_story.html?utm_term=.6d5f465e04fe …

text: Senators voting no on cloture is usually an indication that they are going to vote no on the final vote (which is why Murkowski's no vote here is big). Senators voting yes procedurally could still vote no on the final. Meaning: All eyes on Manchin and Collins.

text: Every week is remarkable. Practically every day is bizarre, every hour unprecedented. So how to describe days that are even more remarkably and bizarrely unprecedented than the last? My look at today’s Washington — and the cliffhanger that never ends:

text: Elizabeth Warren got a standing ovation before and after remarks to the National Congress of American Indians. “We’ve got your back!” the group’s president yelled after her. Reception in the room was all positive.
author: mviser

text: Elizabeth Warren’s husband, Bruce, was here for her speech before the National Congress of American Indians.
author: mviser

text: "We must weave our voices together to make them strong,” Elizabeth Warren says. "We must come together to write a new story, not just for Native Americans, but for all Americans."
author: mviser

text: Elizabeth Warren is making a passionate pledge to advocate for issues of importance for Native Americans. “This must stop,” she says of discrimination and inattention. “And I promise I will fight to help write a different story.”
author: mviser

text: In a major speech for Elizabeth Warren, she addresses a conference of Native Americans. Our story on the breaking news:
author: mviser

text: Elizabeth Warren, speaking to a group of Native Americans: “It is deeply offensive that this President keeps a portrait of Andrew Jackson hanging in the Oval Office, honoring a man who did his best to wipe out Native people.”
author: mviser

text: Elizabeth Warren: “There’s another story that also needs to be told.  The story of our country’s mistreatment of your communities.  And this isn’t just a story about casual racism – war whoops and Tomahawk chops and insulting Facebook memes."
author: mviser

text: “The story they lived will always be a part of me,” Elizabeth Warren says of her parents, and her mother’s heritage. “And no one—not even the President of the United States—will ever take that part of me away.”
author: mviser

text: Warren: “For far too long, your story has been pushed aside, to be trotted out only in cartoons and commercials. So I’m here today to make a promise: Every time someone brings up my family’s story, I’m going to use it to lift up the story of your families and your communities.”
author: mviser

text: Full text of Elizabeth Warren’s speech to the National Congress of American Indians, where she’s making a surprise appearance:
author: mviser

text: Warren is not apologizing for her story, or claims that her mother’s family had Cherokee blood – instead, reaffirming: “My mother’s family was part Native American.”
author: mviser

text: Responding to critics who claim she used a minority status to gain prestigious law professorships, Warren says: “I never used my family tree to get a break or get ahead. I never used it to advance my career.”
author: mviser

text: Elizabeth Warren: “The joke, I guess, is supposed to be on me. I get why some people think there’s hay to be made here. You won’t find my family members on any rolls, and I’m not enrolled in a tribe. And I want to make something clear. I respect that distinction.”
author: mviser

text: Warren directly rebuts Trump: “Indigenous people have been telling the story of Pocahontas–the real Pocahontas–for centuries. A story of heroism. Bravery. Pain. And, for almost as long, her story has been taken away by powerful people who twisted it to serve their own purposes”
author: mviser

text: Warren contrasts the fable of Pocahontas – of a woman who met colonist John Smith, fell in love, and became a positive tale of colonization – with a darker story of abduction and imprisonment.
author: mviser

text: “I’ve noticed that every time my name comes up, President Trump likes to talk about Pocahontas,” Elizabeth Warren says before a conference of Native Americans. “So I figured, let’s talk about Pocahontas.”
author: mviser

text: BREAKING: Elizabeth Warren just took the stage at the National Congress of American Indians. In a surprise appearance, she plans to forcefully rebut Trump’s use of “Pocahontas” as a slur, address the issue of her heritage more directly, and pledge to work on Native issues.
author: mviser

text:
“Mr. President, it would really help if, next time the cameras are in here, you would condemn domestic violence.”
 
“Nah. I don’t think so.”

“Ok. How about a quick statement we could put out?”

“Nope.”

“Well, maybe you could tweet it?”

“I’ll have to get back to you."

text: After Orrin Hatch told Mitt Romney that he wanted him to take his place in the US Senate, Romney chuckled. Romney’s advisers thought it was a “crazy” idea and pointed out many downsides. But over time, Romney warmed to the idea.

text: But two weeks later, Neil Sheehan of the New York Times goes to Cambridge, MA, and checks into the Treadway Motel in Harvard Square. Ellsberg leads him to an apartment and gives the Pentagon Papers to Sheehan. Three months later, the first bombshell report appears.
